question_text: How do different chlorine species (HCl, Cl₂, Cl radicals) affect homogeneous mercury oxidation in coal combustion flue gas, and what is their relative effectiveness?
standard_answer: Chlorine species exhibit distinct roles in homogeneous mercury oxidation due to their varying reactivity and oxidation mechanisms. Cl radicals are the most effective oxidizers, initiating Hg⁰ oxidation through radical reactions. Cl₂ acts as a secondary oxidant that can further oxidize mercury intermediates, though it is less efficient than radicals due to slower kinetics. HCl is the least effective chlorine species for mercury oxidation, requiring higher temperatures for significant reaction. The relative effectiveness follows the order: Cl radical > Cl₂ > HCl. Temperature plays a crucial role in determining which chlorine species dominates mercury oxidation - Cl₂ is more effective at lower temperatures while HCl becomes more favorable at higher temperatures. The oxidation process is kinetically controlled rather than thermodynamically controlled, which explains why measured Hg²⁺ fractions in actual systems (30-95%) differ from equilibrium predictions that would suggest complete oxidation to HgCl₂ below 452°C.
